narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I feel like the course offered a great introduction of financial concepts and offered a really good framework to start thinking about more complex financial topics.
Financial economics
Present and future value, discounting, equity valuation, options, bonds, portfolio optimization
I learned finance theory and lots of math
I learned a lot more about finance in general through this class.
Logical reasoning, application of concepts and formulas to real life examples

Great comprehensive overview to topics in Financial Economics. Helps develop intuition for finance and equips you with technical vocabulary needed in the finance world. Topics covered include time discounting, portfolio choice, equilibrium pricing, arbitrage, market efficiency, equity valuation, fixed-income securities, derivative pricing, and financial intermediation.

I gained a lot of knowledge regarding fundamental concepts in finance like Markets, Risk, CAPM, Portfolio Theory, Asset Classes (Fixed Income, Equity, Derivatives etc.). Learned how to apply this knowledge to everyday happenings in financial markets and how to better digest information regarding finance in the media.
Learned basics of financial economics including CAPM, Financial Intermediation, No Arbitrage, Options, and more

ECON 251 is a great introduction to finance. We cover fixed income, no arbitrage, the efficient frontier, discounting, interest rates, CAPM, Equity Valuation, and options. The class is structured well, and in a chronological manner. If you come in with some introduction to finance, then this class is much easier, you just need to learn the specific ways that Eduardo teaches concepts for the exams. If you come in without ay knowledge, this course builds everything up from the ground up, with intuition.
Financial market structure, bonds, portfolio choice, equity valuation, stock options, mathematical models for financial modeling
I became a lot deeper informed about many of the finance topics that I only understood vaguely.
From the workings of the industry to models like the CAPM and the Black-Scholes
NPV, CAPM, options pricing, arbitrage, fixed income, portfolio theory

Econ 251 provides students with a fantastic thorough background in financial economics. Everything we learn in this class is quantitative, including how to diversify portfolios, how to analyze whether a stock outperforms a benchmark model, how to price stocks, bonds, and options, and the many theoretical ways in which the no arbitrage principle manifests itself.
Knowledge about financial concepts like discounting, valuation, option pricing, fixed income, arbitrage, etc.
A basic understanding of many financial concepts such as portfolio evaluation, yield rates, bonds, etc.
learned about finance
Economics of finance: principles; valuation over time; portfolio selection; derivatives.
Financial economics, very geared towards finance career
Financial Economics.
I learned so much about CAPM, arbitrage pricing, options, etc.
I learned about topics in financial theory such as discounting, CAPM, efficient market hypothesis, fixed income, options, equity valuation, etc.
An understanding of finance and derivatives
Learned all about finance and financial economics -- how the financial system works and how to price financial assets
Financial models
Asset pricing, company valuation, derivative pricing.
Time value of money, interest rates, bond pricing, money markets, stock options

I stepped into this course only knowing basics with regards to financial theory, or more so accounting - such as the three statement financial model, and simple valuation techniques. This class, however, exposed me to quite an in-depth understanding of how finance works. The class takes a more theoretical approach than a qualitative one which helps understanding financial concepts through a mathematical approach.

I came into this class knowing very little about finance. I am grateful to have learned an enormous amount about everything from rates of interest and return, the CAPM model for portfolio choice, fixed income, and arbitrage. The course had a lot of breadth, and I feel like I've learned more over the course of the semester than I have at most classes at Yale.
I learned about the fundamentals of financial economics, including applications of different securities in the real world.

Wonderful course covering the following topics:
 Financial Instruments and Market Structure: Broker-Dealers
 Present/Future Value and Returns: Annuities & Perpetuities: Many problems later on in the course hinge on this concept, that is breaking down assets into their constituent cash flows.
 Portfolio Choice/CAPM
 Market Efficiency: Strong/Semi-Strong/Weak form hypothesis.
 Equity Valuation: Gordon growth model (we didn't spend very much time, here)
 *No Arbitrage and General Equilibrium Pricing*: This is one of the biggest focuses of the course, the "no arbitrage" principle of cash flows pricing. These problems may often involve pricing exotic derivatives (see 2020 practice final exam asking about a "square" derivative for an example). These problems make up the most significant portion of test questions on the final (although there is still a pretty even spread between topics), which I think is fair, since these problems tend to require the most intellectual dexterity and creativity compared to any other problems. A verbatim quote from Professor Davila from the last lecture: I love no arbitrage. :)
 Fixed Income Pricing (Bond Yields & Forward Rates): Very fundamental
 Options: Builds to the black scholes model of option pricing.
 Financial Intermediation

I think that this was a very streamlined course. When I talked to students at other T30 universities, we were learning the same things at Yale. Therefore, note that you are learning fairly fundamental financial economics theories that you can take into any workplace. Everything in this course seems very relevant.

With regards to the syllabus topics covered, I will note that it seems that the course covered slightly more material (1 more block?) in Fall 2021 as opposed to this semester (Fall 2022). I think there was enough space for that one more block, but I think most other students would disagree with me.

As for topics covered, I really think the course would be better if we covered asset classes at some point. Not super extensively, but I think it would have been great if we briefly went over for example in the fixed income block okay class we have: fixed income munis, corporates, high-yield etc. And then you wouldn't need to test anybody on memorizing which bond is which, but it would have made the course a little bit more grounded if it was in the slides somewhere in one place or in a supplementary notebook somewhere.
Learned basic financial concepts and theories. We tested whether those theories truly worked in the real world
Very good primer on finance.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: great content and the professor goes really in-depth
Weaknesses: too fast paced
Strengths: material is important. Weaknesses: the classroom induces sleep. No matter how much coffee I'm on, the classroom puts me to sleep. Don't understand how anyone can stay awake in WLH 201.
The course is very fast paced.

There is a lot of content in the class and so if there was a way to slow it down that would be great but understandable if thats not possible. We learned a lot of major concepts in lecture but on the practice problems a lot of the questions focused on very pointed specific things which were not always covered in class
Class was taught in a very structured, engaging way.
Very little preparation for exams.

Strengths: lecturer clear on important concepts, section solidifies things discussed in lecture
Weaknesses: section on options could use more fleshing out, since it's a lot of information the lectures felt a bit rushed

The lectures were interesting, the slides were comprehensive, the psets were easy, and there were plenty of practice questions to prepare for the exams. 
The structure felt pretty rigid and it felt like Prof Davila was sometimes just reading off of the slides. The course also leaned heavily towards the theoretical and academic side of financial economics -- sometimes I wish there was more direct applicability to the real world.

The strengths are definitely the material taught as no other undergraduate economics elective at Yale offers such a broad and yet detailed intro to the world of finance. The course was designed well and covers the key concepts in every area from which you can build on further to understand more complex problems. A weakness for some might be that the pace at which the course is taught is quite fast, and it can be difficult to keep up especially towards the end when the material is more challenging. No other weaknesses as such.
The lectures were really hard to stay engaged with

Strengths: Covers all the main topics of finance in a well organized manner. There are a ton of practice problems to prep for the exams you should def do them.
Weaknesses: There are only 7 psets, which cover very specific parts of the course, so you don't get a ton of practice on all course material through the psets. You get it by doing the practice problems.

Strengths: engaging prof, interesting material, good psets. Weaknesses: lectures are sometimes hard to follow (but mostly great! prof just sometimes underestimates the difficulty of some of the material)
final was way harder than I expected :(
The course was well structured, had some very interesting topics and a lot of practice materials to solidify our understanding and prepare us for exams.

Strenghts: Prof Davila is fantastic; I love his slides and teaching style, especially his breaks for reviewing the essentials of everything we just went through. The extra practice material with solutions is amazing; I wish more courses had something like it.

Weaknesses: exams always felt more like a battle against time than the exam itself.
A little too theoretical, wish there was more practical applications of the material!

Strengths: Eduardo, great content, so much extra material given 
Weaknesses: Yale no longer teaching ECON 252

Professor Davila is the true strength of this course. His teaching style enables him to cover many concepts in depth in just one semester. He is incredibly succinct and introduces new material in simple, manageable steps; his crystal-clear explanations enable him to move quickly and dive deeply into intricate, densely mathematical ideas. Another significant strength of the course is that the problem sets are similar to the material covered in class, and the exams reflect the material covered in class, problem sets, and practice material. At every step, Professor Davilas students practice concepts that will be useful, and this multiaxial reinforcement helped us solidify our understanding of the material every step of the way.

Strengths - great professor, lots of practice material, and very well-planned
Weaknesses - the cumulative final was a lot of material to cover in reading period. The course introduces a lot of unrelated topics and sometimes it can get a bit confusing.

strengths: Prof Davila was amazing and really good at explaining tough concepts in class. Also, a large amount of practice materials were provided which made learning the concepts easier. 
weaknesses: Sometimes the teacher went fast in class, but normally important things were repeated several times
good class
A bit too niche/intensive in the latter part of the course, take out some material and slow it down at the end
Not the best slides if you missed a lecture, had to be focused the entire lecture or else you would struggle to understand what was happening next. Good sections and plenty of practice materials.
Covers a large variety of topics, and the slides are very useful when studying.

Strengths: Very good introduction to financial theory. Well-taught, organized course.

Weaknesses: Some of the equations were given without rigorous proof.
The course was relatively slow paced, making things easy to understand but not very engaging.

Strengths - Davila, the content, the clarity of lectures
Weaknesses - went too fast at times, but very few

The course gives you a very good overview of financial markets, like portfolio mix, market structures, interest rates, derivatives, bonds, bonds valuation, and other very applied topics. However, it is a huge amount of information in such a little time (also in the lectures) what can make the course a little difficult to be up to date with the lectures.
Class went too fast.
Problem sets could more accurately reflect the difficulty of the midterm and final. More examples in class would also be helpful.

Strengths: The instructor is great, you can really see his passion towards his field demonstrated in class with regards to how in-depth he goes with concepts. The class keeps you up to date with any recent problems in the financial world, so you can definitely cut back on reading The Economist for some time.  It's designed to wake up your inner finance bro. 

Weaknesses: There is too much to cover in too little time. At certain instances I felt the instructor was cramming together too many things which left me unclear with regards to grassroots level concepts. I also felt that the TA sections were a repetition of the class sides, and no new practice was being included. Lastly the exams were quite hard, and although adequate preparation material was required, questions with regards to the linear asset pricing model, and pricing of assets in different states were not discussed in class with the importance they held in exams.

I think that it would be nice to have more review sessions before exams available to students, especially before final exams. I also wish that we had more graded worksheets/homeworks rather than fewer psets. I would rather have the time pressure to do more problems than the expectation to do the numerical questions on my own, and having opportunities to go over more problems with TA's would have been helpful.
Overall structure is good, however, unit on arbitrage felt a little bit rushed, so if possible in the future you could spend more time on it.

As many of the other course reviews state, the problem sets were very brief and easy. The exams and midterm were just much harder than the problem sets. So, for the typical students (poor planning skills) this causes them to relatively coast through most weeks of the course and then just do tons of work and tons of practice problems for the week before the final and midterm. You can't argue that this is necessarily the professor's fault, though. Nonetheless, I think that making harder problem sets could have "forced" us to spread our studying out more.

I will say that, I think there was a fantastic reservoir of practice exam/midterm problems to study. By far the best and most extensive out of any course I have taken at Yale. If you do a couple hundred practice problems on your own I think you will do well on the assessments.

Also, I think there were some really nice supplementary textbook and notebook readings. Nobody is going to test you on how to construct an iron condor vs iron butterfly option strategy, but if you wanted to teach yourself about those topics, outside of class time, there were good resources for you to learn about those things if you're passionate about learning financial economics for its own sake.

As Professor Davila says, this is supposed to be a course that "makes you think." Therefore, the class definitely focused on critical problem solving rather than rote memorization (really minimal "plug and chug" component to the course) which is probably one of the biggest aims to which professors aspire. So, good job!

The material in the course was extremely well organized and went through at a good pace. A potential weakness is that grades were highly determined by one's performace on the midterm and final exam, though there is a lot of practice material provided to help do well.
Great class!

Prof moves a little fast in class and doesn't always explain things very clearly. However, the class covers a broad range of topics that you will learn if you attend section and devote time outside of lecture.

In general, I do not like the teaching methodology of going from bullet point to bullet point from slide to slide. No narrative structure to demonstrate purpose of unit/module within the overarching context of the class, which necessitates the requirement of TA sections to "reinforce" (reiterate word-for-word is more apt) what was discussed in lecture. Students just end up learning the entirety of the content themselves on their own time - faster to just read the slides then hear the slides from Prof/TA.

But ultimately this flaw is not unique to specifically ECON 251, but rather a more structural problem within the Economics department. So, would still recommend taking the class. Good theoretical framework for any student interested in finance.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Great Class for an all-you-need finance class.
Yes, especially if you want to learn a good conceptual framework to think about asset valuation, portfolio management, fixed-income and derivatives.
Yes, if interested in financial economics.
Yes, it is a good econ elective, especially if you are looking to go into the world of finance.
Yes if they want to learn finance theory. This will not help with investment banking, but is a prerequisite for higher finance courses. I would only recommend if you are majoring in economics
Yes! Good to know financial basics.
Yes, I thought that the professor was very excited about what he was teaching and the course was a good introduction to finance
Yes if they are interested in finance.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in working in Finance (Investment Banking, Private Equity, Hedge Funds etc), as the course teaches the fundamentals of everything you need to know to go into such fields. I wouldn't really recommend this course if you're casually interested as it goes really in depth and you might find it too challenging and theoretical at times.

I would. But also not if you arent interested in the material. Also remember that many people will be coming in at different levels (probably should not take if you have already done a finance internship)
I would recommend this course to another student. If you follow the right steps, then you can learn a lot and do well in the course
Yes, useful material to learn about even if you aren't into quant or finance. The course is very well-taught, challenging, but not burdensome in terms of workload

I definitely would, as after taking this course, a lot of the finance topics that made no sense to me suddenly became very easy. Taking this course allowed me to see a more theoretical side of finance.
Great for anyone remotely interested in finance

Depends on what you're looking for. If taking this class to prepare for an internship like I intended to, then no (not a lot of practical applications). But if interested in financial theory, yes. Probably best to take if you already have some experience.
Yes great way to learn about financial econ
100%, especially with Eduardo

Absolutely. This course provides a fantastic in-depth overview of financial economics. I feel like I have a much better understanding of not just how to price different securities, but also the way the financial system works in general. The discussion sections are also fantastic, since they recap the complicated course material as we learn. It was incredibly helpful to do practice problems as a group as we learned the material.
Yes! Especially if you're considering a career in finance

I would recommend this course to another student if there are interested in developing a better understanding of common financial jargon and topics. There is a good amount of math involved in some concepts but professor davila does a good job explaining everything you need to know.

Yes, I would. It is a fantastic introduction to the world of finance and gives you the basic tools to make sense of the news and how to think critically about financial and investment opportunities. Needless to say, the class is essential for those looking to go into finance, buying would also recommend it to anyone remotely interested because of how broadly applicable this knowledge is in the future.
Only if they are actually going into finance. I have an interest in it but since I'm not doing it as a career it was too niche
Yes, super cool to learn about finance.
Yes - it was a great class to learn about the building blocks of finance.

Highly recommend! This course is great if you're interested in anything related to the financial world. You learn a lot of cool things about equities, fixed income, options, and more. There is a little bit of math involved but everything is explained well by the professor / teaching fellows.
I would recommend this course to someone interested in finance.
Yes - this content is great to learn whether or not you want to work in finance.
Yes useful knowing in finance
If you are interested in going into Finance - investment banking, hedge funds, and wealth management - then yes!
Absolutely - I really enjoyed the material and learned a lot.
I would recommend this course to any student pursuing a career in finance, as you learn a lot of applicable skills regarding stocks, bonds, and other securities.

Yes. Would recommend.

If you're somebody with stronger quantitative skills, then you will also do well in this course. For example, the CAPM section covers lots of correlation/covariance and if you took mathematical stats or linear algebra then you know that the covariance operator forms an inner product, so you can just solve those problems straight away. Yet if you don't know anything about linear algebra at all, then the problems are still just as solvable. Knowing a bunch of math will probably make this course easier for you. You could not say the same thing about the intro micro/macro sequence for example. So, just be aware of that fact.

Note also that there are many students in this course who are highly focused on investment banking or some sort of financial career, who will put lots of work into the course.

Tough class with lots of smart people in it. Although Econ curve is generous. Definitely useful if interested in finance. Professor is very smart and good at explaining concepts, but he sometimes talks too fast to understand and goes into unnecessary detail (lecture slides are thorough but not efficient)
Take this course if you want to learn the theory behind financial markets but note that some of these theories don't work in practice
Yes for those interested in finance (genuine or not). Absolutely.
